linkTarget.anchoringText: The seismically defined structure is an elongated low relief structure on a NW-SE trend. This field is structurally complicated and highly faulted which then led to compartmentalization of the field into separate fault blocks with different fluid contacts. The fault blocks are defined as Proven, Probable, and Possible as portrayed in Figure 1.

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: Structural cross section showing proven and possible hydrocarbon distribution along with the compartmentalization perception of the field.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Structural cross section showing proven and possible hydrocarbon distribution along with the compartmentalization perception of the field.

linkTarget.anchoringText: In 1993, an early production scheme (EPS) was started to gather production data in order to identify the main uncertainties and test the feasibility of the full field development. The field produced oil and gas from 1993 to 1999. Monitoring the average reservoir pressure against cumulative production would indicate an average initial reservoir pressure of x090 psi with a range of +/- 75 psi at a datum level. During the years of production, a number of pressure build-up tests (PBU) for the producers and static bottom hole pressure tests in the observer wells had been taken. The results of those tests are given in Figure 2.

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: Summary of reservoir closed-in pressure data.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Summary of reservoir closed-in pressure data.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The main hydrocarbon bearing reservoir in the field is a heterogeneous carbonate reservoir and is characterized by its marked vertical facies changes wackestone/ mudstone in the lower part while grading upward into foraminiferal grainstone/packstone. Based on the lithology variation, the reservoir could be subdivided into seven facies units. The reservoir represents a regressive depositional sequence starting with low energy (the LM facies) and ending with shallow marine high energy shoal deposits of the RO facies. The facies identified are from top to bottom RO, Ml, R1, M2, R2, M3A and LM as shown in Figure 3.

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: Stratigraphy zonation, sub-zones used to build static model.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Stratigraphy zonation, sub-zones used to build static model.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Porosity. Twenty-six (26) cores with a total length of 951 ft were cut within the reservoir from ten (10) wells. The overall core recovery is around 68%. Routine core analysis was performed on plugs taken at regularly spaced intervals of one feet. In general, the core plugs porosity is matching with log porosity after overburden pressure correction except on the upper part of reservoir due to heterogeneities. The degree of compaction and subsequent formation of stylolites down flank is considered to be responsible for the thickness reduction and the deterioration of the average porosity towards the flank (Figure 4).

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: Well Section showing porosity and permeability variation vertically and laterally.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Well Section showing porosity and permeability variation vertically and laterally.

linkTarget.anchoringText: For the scope of this work, the evaluation is mainly focused on the proven blocks and for this paper we would like to highlight the approach followed to derive the poro-perm relationships. Porosity/permeability relationships, corrected for overburden pressure, have been derived from routine core data for every subzone. This has been applied to log derived porosity to obtain permeability in the non-cored sections using neural network. With the limited amount of available data, utilizing the neural networks approach had improved the data representation compared to conventional approaches, as can be clearly observed from (Figure 5).

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: New poro-perm cross plot generated using neural networks.

formatted-caption.caption-text: New poro-perm cross plot generated using neural networks.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The workflow used to build the new static model is shown in the Figure 6, which starts from data validation to building a new structural framework and grid, redefining the previous model intorducing more details in each cell. The Property modeling was made using trends and rock typing guides.

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: Workflow implemented to build the new static model.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Workflow implemented to build the new static model.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The structural model was compared with old model, interpretation and the regional structural model as part of QC and the new model is following the regional trend (Figure 7).

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: Structural modeling and structure framework QCed.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Structural modeling and structure framework QCed.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The same workflow of the previous model was used, but in the new static model (fine grid), the interpreted porosity logs were correlated with the core values and a merge was made to capture the high values in the upper part of Zone I and honoring all porosity values; arithmetic averaging was used for upscaling, getting good results given the high vertical resolution (Figure 8).

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: Upscaled porosity and permeability logs, example from wells 1 and 7 into the new fine grid.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Upscaled porosity and permeability logs, example from wells 1 and 7 into the new fine grid.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The two developed EOS mimicking the compositional variation across the reservoir through 8 pseudo components, good matched the routine experiments of the honored PVT studies (Figure 9).

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: Matching of PVT paramters utilizing EOS (Data shown is for Block A, same pseudo component is used).

formatted-caption.caption-text: Matching of PVT paramters utilizing EOS (Data shown is for Block A, same pseudo component is used).

linkTarget.anchoringText: The historical test data, BHP and THP were used as guidance for improving history match. The new model resulted in much better history match in comparison to Old Model as shown in Figure 10.

image-wrap.label: Figure 10
image-wrap.caption: Comparison between match quality of old and new model (Better improvement of the new model History Match).

formatted-caption.caption-text: Comparison between match quality of old and new model (Better improvement of the new model History Match).

linkTarget.anchoringText: Prediction runs were performed for different recovery mechanisms to assist decision on the best development scheme. The development scenarios considered the following list of recovery mechanisms with new eight horizontal producers and 7 new injectors with specified field and well constraints (Figure 11).

image-wrap.label: Figure 11
image-wrap.caption: Proposed well locations of the development options.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Proposed well locations of the development options.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Comparison of the different development options along with their corresponding sensitivities indicate that the pure gas injection yields the best recovery while water injection would be the worst. As expected, the WAG injection would be strongly affected by the heterogeneity and the complexity of the rock that would directly impact the effectiveness of the water cycle. The prediction runs suggested that gas injection would be able to maintain the reservoir pressure compared to the WAG (Figures 12 to 20).

image-wrap.label: Figure 12
image-wrap.caption: Oil production profiles under different recovery mechanims.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Oil production profiles under different recovery mechanims.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Comparison of the different development options along with their corresponding sensitivities indicate that the pure gas injection yields the best recovery while water injection would be the worst. The prediction runs suggested that gas injection would be able to maintain the reservoir pressure compared to the WAG (Figures 12 to 20).

linkTarget.anchoringText: The final optimized subsurface locations are shown in Figures 21 and the simulation results Figures 22-26. Based on the prediction runs, developing the gas cap seems promising and in line with the other new existing conditions of low oil prices and increasing gas demand. Therefore and given all the circumstances, the development mindset is adapted towards the gas cap development, after it was originally set on oil development. Yet, the dynamic model is constructed with advanced tracking in order to identify and maximize the condensate and gas production from gas cap also to assess the future opportunities of targeting the bypassed hydrocarbon.

image-wrap.label: Figure 21
image-wrap.caption: Gas cap proposed subsurface locations.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Gas cap proposed subsurface locations.
